SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Follow-up of chronic problems.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling fatigued, lightheaded, and bloated for the past five weeks. He has been experiencing some shortness of breath during physical activities and occasional chest cramps. He has a slight cough, which he attributes to the change of seasons. The patient has been compliant with his medications but admits to struggling with his diet due to recent home renovations.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses fatigue, lightheadedness, bloating, shortness of breath, and chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Endorses a slight cough.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm. 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema of the bilateral lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Shows fluid in the lungs.

Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Ejection fraction of 45%. Mitral regurgitation present.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is retaining fluid, as evidenced by the physical exam and chest X-ray findings.
• Additional Testing: Order a new echocardiogram.
• Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily, call if weight gain occurs, and report any shortness of breath.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to continue recording blood pressures at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of right knee pain after a fall from a ladder while changing a light bulb yesterday. She reports that she twisted her knee while trying to catch her fall. She denies any other injuries.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS:

Digoxin

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:

Atrial Fibrillation

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY:

Rhinoplasty

EXAM

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial meniscus area. There is pain with flexion and valgus stress. Sensation is normal.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee show no fractures or dislocations. There is a small amount of fluid present.

IMPRESSION

Acute medial meniscus sprain or strain of the right knee.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I recommend a knee brace and crutches for temporary use. The patient will return in one week for a follow-up evaluation, and if not improved, we will consider an MRI. I will prescribe Motrin 800 mg every 6 hours with food for pain relief, with a two-week supply. All questions were answered.

CC:

Lower back pain.

HPI:

Mr. Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, who presents today with lower back pain. He reports lifting heavy boxes too quickly while helping his daughter with some equipment on Saturday. He heard a pop in his back and experienced pain, which has persisted since then. He has tried Tylenol, ibuprofen, and icy heat, but these have not provided relief. He experienced tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon. He finds it difficult to find a comfortable sleeping position but lying on his right side seems to help.

EXAM

Examination of the lower back shows pain to palpation of the lumbar spine and pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise. Blood pressure is elevated in the office. Heart exam reveals a 2/6 systolic heart murmur, which has been stable.

RESULTS

Diabetes labs: Hemoglobin A1c is elevated at 8.
Back X-ray: Normal bony alignment, no fracture present.

IMPRESSION

1. Lumbar strain
2. Diabetes type 2, poorly controlled
3. Hypertension
4. Osteoarthritis

PLAN

1. Lumbar strain: Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg once a day, continue icing, avoid strenuous activity, and refer to physical therapy.
2. Diabetes type 2: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice a day, repeat hemoglobin A1c in 6 months.
3. Hypertension: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.
4. Osteoarthritis: Continue monitoring knee, no further workup needed at this time.

The patient understands and agrees with the recommended treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam, depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, hypertension, and prior lobectomy, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports a relatively stable mood with compliance to Prozac for depression. He has been struggling with hypertension, occasionally forgetting to take his medication on weekends. He denies any significant shortness of breath or issues related to his prior lobectomy.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies weight loss. Denies fever or chills.
• Respiratory: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses occasional chest pounding during exercise.
• ENT: Endorses nasal congestion.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• ENT: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: 120/80.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient reports compliance with Prozac and stable mood.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily. Refill provided.

2. Prior lobectomy.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient denies significant shortness of breath or issues related to lobectomy. Chest X-ray appears normal.
   • Medical Treatment: No further follow-up with the surgeon needed at this time.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled in the office, despite occasional missed doses on weekends.
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram for the murmur.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Norvasc as prescribed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up as needed and communicate through the patient portal for any concerns or test results.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right index finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of right index finger pain. She reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her ski pole strap caught on her finger, causing it to bend back. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has tried applying ice and taking Ibuprofen, but the pain persists. The patient also reports recent constipation, for which she takes Miralax.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Constipation.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Appendectomy at age 18.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Right index finger: Tenderness over the distal phalanx and pain with flexion. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint.
• Range of motion: Patient is able to bend and extend the finger and touch the thumb with it.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right index finger show no evidence of fracture. Everything lines up well.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female who presents today for evaluation of right index finger pain after a skiing incident.

Right index finger contusion.
• Medical Reasoning: Based on the physical examination and normal x-ray, the patient has a contusion on the tip of her right index finger without fracture.
• Medical Treatment: We will provide an aluminum foam splint for support and prescribe Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for pain relief.
• Patient Education and Counseling: The patient should continue the treatment for about a week and contact us if the pain does not improve.

Constipation.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient is currently taking Miralax for constipation.
• Medical Treatment: Continue with Miralax as needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia since the age of 13. She recently attempted to donate blood in December 2019 and was informed of her anemia. The patient reports fatigue, feverish feelings, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She also experiences cold intolerance and worsening anxiety and depression. She had a hysterectomy in 1996 and her last colonoscopy was approximately 5-6 years ago with no significant findings. She denies having a pacemaker, defibrillator, sleep apnea, or using oxygen at night. She drinks alcohol occasionally and is currently taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen is non-tender to palpation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Christina Cooper is a 65-year-old female with a history of iron deficiency anemia.

Iron deficiency anemia.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a long-standing history of anemia and is currently experiencing fatigue, feverish feelings, chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. She is taking ferrous sulfate and vitamin B12.
• Additional Testing: Schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 12 weeks.
• Medical Treatment: Continue ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Continue over-the-counter vitamin B12.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient to schedule an upper endoscopy and colonoscopy and to follow up with a hematologist. Provide instructions for bowel prep and advise the patient to call if there are any questions or worsening symptoms.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with no significant past medical history who presents with worsening headaches over the past few months. He denies any history of headaches. The patient was referred by Dr. Henry Howard for possible surgical intervention due to the incidental discovery of a pituitary lesion during the workup for his headaches. The patient's laboratory results, including CBC, UNES, UH, coagulation, and CRP, were all normal. Pituitary hormone profile demonstrates a low TSH, with all other results being normal. MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Neurological: Endorses worsening headaches, dizziness, and bumping into door frames.
• Ophthalmologic: Denies changes in vision or balance.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Neurological: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent. Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities.
• Ophthalmologic: Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Mr. Bruce Ward is a 52-year-old male with worsening headaches and an incidental pituitary lesion.

Pituitary adenoma.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression due to a pituitary lesion, which is likely a benign pituitary adenoma.
• Additional Testing: We will order a visual field test and refer the patient to an eye doctor for a full exam.
• Surgical Treatment: We will proceed with a transsphenoidal approach for surgical intervention to excise and decompress the pituitary fossa. The patient has been informed of the risks associated with anesthesia and surgery.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and difficulty swallowing.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal, who presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient experienced chest pain and difficulty swallowing in early October 2020, which resolved after four days. She has not had any recurrence of these symptoms since then. The patient reports that the chest pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The pain was worse with eating. She denies any current abdominal pain or issues with bowel movements.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematemesis, hematochezia, melena, heartburn, or abdominal pain.
• Genitourinary: Denies urinary urgency, pain, or incontinence.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies lower right side back pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. No murmurs, gallops, or rubs. No extra heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No rebound or guarding. No peritoneal signs.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Betty Hill is a 53-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal, who presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis.

Possible etiologies:
• GERD
• Dyspepsia
• Esophagitis
• Musculoskeletal etiologies
• Anxiety

Suspect she had an anxiety attack related to her job transition, plus or minus a contribution from her musculoskeletal etiologies.

Plan:
• Discussed the option of EGD versus monitoring for symptoms. The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change.
• Follow up as needed for any other GI complaints.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Evaluation of kidneys due to Smith-Magenis Syndrome.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome who presents for evaluation of her kidneys. She is a twin and was born at 34 weeks and 3 days gestation. The patient has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently receiving feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. The patient has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, who mentioned potential kidney issues related to her syndrome.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General Examination: Well-nourished female, slightly fussy when examined.
• Eyes: Small appearing.
• Musculoskeletal: Mild hypotonia of the lower extremities and arms.
• Genitourinary: Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Katherine is a 22-month-old female with Smith-Magenis Syndrome who presents for evaluation of her kidneys. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature for patients with this syndrome.

• Additional Testing: We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today.
• Follow-up: If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

Patient Agreements: The patient's family understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist pain and swelling after a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Diana is a patient who presents with right wrist pain and swelling after falling while carrying a laundry basket down the stairs. She reports severe pain (9/10) and has tried ice, an ace wrap, and ibuprofen for relief with minimal success. The injury occurred yesterday morning.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss.
Musculoskeletal: Endorses right wrist pain and swelling.
Neurological: Reports mild tingling in fingers.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Obvious swelling and bruising of the right wrist, tenderness on palpation, and pain with flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Able to make a fist but not tightly.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 140/70 mmHg
Temperature: 97.2 degrees F
Heart Rate: 80 bpm
Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths/min

RESULTS

X-ray of the right wrist: Positive for a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Colles' fracture of the right wrist.
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with severe pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the right wrist after a fall. X-ray confirms the presence of a Colles' fracture.
- Medical Treatment: Place the patient in a brace and schedule surgery as soon as possible. Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours for pain management.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Instruct the patient on the importance of attending physical therapy post-surgery to regain strength and prevent future injury. Discuss the possibility of postponing vacation plans depending on the progress of recovery and physical therapy recommendations.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Philip is a 52-year-old male with a past medical history of hypertension who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. He reports that he slipped and fell while working on his property a week ago and has been experiencing knee pain since then. He has been taking ibuprofen for the swelling. He rates the pain as 4/10 when moving the knee. He has been taking his hypertension medication (Lisinopril 20 mg) regularly but admits to not making significant changes to his diet.

EXAM

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness over the medial aspect. Swelling and effusion are noted. Pain with flexion and extension of the knee.

RESULTS

X-rays of the right knee show no obvious signs of acute fracture or bony abnormalities.

IMPRESSION

Right knee medial collateral ligament (MCL) strain.

PLAN

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have prescribed ibuprofen 800 mg to take twice daily for pain and swelling. I will also provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times a day. I advised the patient to elevate and rest the leg as needed.

For his hypertension, I will continue the Lisinopril 20 mg daily and refer the patient to a nutritionist to help with dietary modifications. The patient will follow up with me as needed if he continues to have pain or concerns. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Wayne is a patient who presents with left shoulder pain for the past three weeks. He is unable to recall any specific injury but has been active and doing a lot of work in his basement recently. He has had occasional aches and pains in the past but nothing that Tylenol couldn't alleviate. The current pain is constant and worsens with pressure or reaching for objects. He has been taking two extra strength Tylenol every six to eight hours, which provides some relief but not complete resolution of the pain. He denies any numbness or tingling in his arms or hands.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses left shoulder pain and limited range of motion.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Limited active and passive range of motion in the left shoulder. Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus. No tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints. Good hand grips.
• Neurovascular: Capillary refill is less than three seconds in the left arm. Sensation is intact to light touch.

RESULTS

X-ray of the left shoulder: No fractures.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Wayne presents with left shoulder pain, most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy.

1. Rotator cuff tendinopathy.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical exam findings are consistent with an injury to the tendons of the shoulder muscles.
   • Additional Testing: We will order an MRI of the left shoulder to further evaluate the injury.
   • Medical Treatment: Refer the patient to physical therapy for 6-8 weeks. The patient may continue taking Tylenol for pain relief. If symptoms do not improve, we can consider a steroid injection for the shoulder.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: The nurse will provide educational materials on physical therapy and what to expect during the treatment process.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after completing physical therapy.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports occasional left knee pain that occurs less than once a day while walking. The pain is described as the whole kneecap "giving out" and is not associated with any specific movement or injury. The patient denies any history of injury to the left knee and has not taken any medication for the pain, as it does not last long. The patient is concerned about an upcoming trip involving walking and line dancing, and plans to avoid participating in the dancing due to the knee pain.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension
Diabetes Mellitus

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril
Amlodipine
Hydrochlorothiazide
Farxiga
Metformin

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Left knee - no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee x-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT

1. Left knee pain, likely arthritis.
2. Hypertension.
3. Diabetes Mellitus.

PLAN

1. Left knee pain:
   - Prescribe Meloxicam 15 mg daily.
   - Consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee.
2. Hypertension:
   - Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily.
   - Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.
3. Diabetes Mellitus:
   - Order Hemoglobin A1C to assess need for Metformin adjustment.
   - Order lipid panel.

INSTRUCTIONS

Continue current medications as prescribed. Schedule echocardiogram and follow up with results. Call with any questions or concerns.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage 3 non-small cell lung cancer who presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule, and biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma. Molecular testing is pending at this time. The patient reports minimal cough and sore throat today, with no shortness of breath. She has been experiencing some fatigue but denies nausea or vomiting.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient has good family support and has been receiving assistance from the nursing staff and office.

TREATMENT

Currently on a combination of cisplatin and etoposide chemotherapy.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Stable, oxygen levels satisfactory.
Neck: No cervical or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Crackles bilaterally.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, likely related to radiation.
Lower extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lung cancer: Continue with the current chemotherapy regimen of cisplatin and etoposide, as well as the current dose of radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion of radiation to assess tumor size for potential surgical removal.

2. Radiation pneumonitis: Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and alleviate cough and shortness of breath.

3. Painful swallowing: Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow (four times a day) to help with eating and drinking, prevent dehydration, and minimize further weight loss.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Kyle is a patient who presents today with concerns about a low immunoglobulin A level, as reported by their primary care physician. The patient has a recent diagnosis of type 2 diabetes and is currently taking metformin. They report a history of frequent colds during the winter months, which tend to linger for a long time. The patient denies any recent abdominal infections or diarrhea. There is no known family history of immune deficiencies.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Type 2 diabetes.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient's family owns a donut shop. The patient has recently traveled to Zambia.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known immune deficiencies.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Metformin.

PHYSICAL EXAM

• Vitals: Stable, no fever.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
• Abdominal: Soft, non-tender.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Low immunoglobulin A level.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's lab work is consistent with an IgA deficiency, which is a common immunodeficiency. Most people with this deficiency live normal lives without complications. The patient does not report significant issues with infections.
   • Additional Testing: Order blood work to check for other antibody levels to rule out other immunodeficiencies.
   • Patient Education: Instruct the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they ever need blood products.

2. Type 2 diabetes.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is currently taking metformin for their diabetes.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue metformin as prescribed and monitor blood sugar levels.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up after lab work is completed. They should report any significant changes in their health, such as persistent infections or severe diarrhea.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right elbow pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Lawrence is a patient who presents with right elbow pain that started about 4 days ago. He reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery during the pandemic and believes this may have contributed to the pain. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and sometimes radiates down into his forearm. He denies any trauma or previous injury to the elbow. The pain is rated as a 6/10 and has been affecting his sleep and daily activities. He has tried ibuprofen for pain relief with minimal success.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right elbow pain and discomfort in the forearm.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Positive for pain to palpation at the medial epicondyle of the right elbow. Pain with pronation of the forearm. Pain with resistance against flexion of the right wrist.

VITALS REVIEWED

• Blood Pressure: Within normal limits.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right elbow: No fracture or bony abnormality detected.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Lawrence presents with right elbow pain, likely due to overuse from pottery activities.

Medial epicondylitis.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's symptoms and physical examination findings are consistent with medial epicondylitis, caused by overuse and potential damage to the tendons that bend the wrist towards the palm.
• Medical Treatment: Rest the affected arm, wear a sling while awake, apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes three times a day, and take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Advised the patient to avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks to allow the elbow to heal.
• Follow-up: Schedule a follow-up appointment in one week to assess progress.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a patient who presents with a recent history of chest pain and shortness of breath. He reports falling down while walking outside and experiencing chest pain, which he initially attributed to heartburn. He also reports shortness of breath but did not think much of it. He was seen in the emergency department where it was noted that his ankles were swelling, and his blood pressure was 200/90. The patient admits to occasionally missing his hypertension medications and not adhering to a low-salt diet.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension

SOCIAL HISTORY

Quit smoking a couple of years ago, with occasional lapses.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Bumex 2 mg once daily
Cozaar 100 mg daily
Norvasc 5 mg once daily

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 128/72, other vital signs within normal limits.
Neck: No jugular venous distention.
Heart: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
Lungs: Clear bilaterally.
Lower extremities: Trace edema.

RESULTS

Echocardiogram: Preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT

• Congestive heart failure, likely due to dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.

PLAN

1. Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily.
2. Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily.
3. Continue Norvasc 5 mg once daily.
4. Consult nutrition for dietary advice and salt restriction.
5. Obtain a scale for daily weight monitoring; call if weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
6. Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out other causes.
7. Encourage medication adherence and smoking cessation.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up with nutritionist and monitor weight daily. Take medications as prescribed and call if any concerns arise. Schedule renal artery ultrasound.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right-sided abdominal pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Russell is a patient who presents with sharp pain on the right side of his abdomen below his ribs for the last several days. The pain moves to his lower abdomen and into his groin. The pain is intermittent and severe, making it difficult for him to find a comfortable position. He reports mild burning during urination and dark-colored urine. He has taken Tylenol for pain with minimal relief. The patient feels nauseated but has not vomited. He has a family history of kidney stones and has had them in the past but was able to pass them.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
CVA: Positive tenderness on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen: 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT

Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).

PLAN

1. Encourage increased fluid intake to facilitate urination and stone passage.
2. Prescribe oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain. Continue alternating with Tylenol.
3. Provide a urine strainer for the patient to catch the stone when it passes.
4. Order a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
5. Schedule a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks to assess progress. Discuss further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy if symptoms persist or worsen.

INSTRUCTIONS

Return to the clinic in 1-2 weeks or contact the clinic if symptoms worsen.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a middle-aged male who presents for evaluation of a nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on his right foot. The patient has had the ulcer for about six weeks, which started as a blister after wearing tight shoes. The patient reports a foul smell, yellow drainage, and the ulcer has turned black around the outside. He has been on antibiotics for six days and has experienced some chills and a fever of 99.7°F. The patient also reports cramping in his calf muscle and a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle. The patient has a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, with a recent A1C of 6.7.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Integumentary: Positive for nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer, foul smell, yellow drainage, and blackened tissue around the ulcer.
• Musculoskeletal: Positive for cramping in the calf muscle.
• Vascular: Positive for red streak along the inside portion of the calf muscle.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
• Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the right heel, approximately 2x2 cm, sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythema, and odor present. No bony exposure.
• Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses. Nonpalpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

RESULTS

Right foot x-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient presents with a nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer on the right foot.

1. Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, and the ulcer is not healing despite antibiotic treatment.
   • Additional Testing: Order a test to check blood supply for the wound.
   • Medical Treatment: Perform debridement in the office, obtain a culture, and consider different antibiotic therapy based on culture results. Monitor the redness and swelling in the calf closely. Follow up in 7 days.

2. Diabetes management
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's A1C is currently well-controlled, but blood sugars have been trending higher recently.
   • Medical Treatment: Encourage the patient to follow up with their endocrinologist and continue to keep their A1C below 7. Monitor blood sugars closely during treatment for the foot ulcer.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Richard is a patient who presents with a tick bite on his right knee, which he noticed over a week ago. He reports spending time outdoors, including hunting and working in his yard. The tick bite area feels warm and has been causing burning and discomfort. He denies fever, chills, joint pain, and difficulty moving his knee. He has not experienced any issues with walking. He has had tick bites in the past but has never been diagnosed with Lyme disease. Since the tick bite, he has been experiencing headaches and a general feeling of unwellness.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Hypertension: Taking lisinopril, blood pressure controlled.
Diabetes: Taking metformin, blood sugars in the 120s.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Skin: Tick bite on right knee, bull's-eye rash.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee discomfort.
Neurological: No issues with walking or moving knee.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 122/70, heart rate 67, temperature 98.4.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Right Knee: Erythema, edema, area of fluctuance over right patella, pain to palpation, full range of motion.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: Presence of bull's-eye rash and tick bite on right knee.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for 3 weeks.
- Additional Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm Lyme disease diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure controlled with lisinopril.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once daily.
- Additional Testing: Order lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: Blood sugars controlled with metformin.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice daily.
- Additional Testing: Order hemoglobin A1c and basic metabolic panel to assess long-term blood sugar control and kidney function.

INSTRUCTIONS

Follow up in 3 weeks to assess response to doxycycline treatment and review test results. Call clinic with any additional concerns or worsening symptoms.
